titleInfo.title: Composing Commitment
titleInfo.subTitle: Diversity Statements on the Writing Studies Job Market

mods:mods.abstract: Over the years, writing studies scholarship on academic labor has focused primarily on the effects of neoliberalism's effects on the academy (Carter; Hendricks; Kahn and Pason; Scott; Winslow), especially for non-tenured employees (Connors; Doe; Hansel and Baird Giordano; Hansen; Horner; Klausman; Mechenbier; Penrose; Sledd; Taylor et al.). However, there has been a shift to study how other academics navigate their careers by studying emotion/emotional labor (Caswell et al.; Geller and Denny; Micciche) and the experiences of graduate students (Edgington and Taylor; Miller; Mountford). That said, with the exception of Carmen Kynard's, Craig Lamont's, and Staci M. Perryman-Clark's work, academic labor scholarship doesn't extensively connect the concept of "advocacy" while also considering facets of workers' identity (e.g., ability, race, gender, and sexuality). Studying professional documents can provide valuable insights into how individuals in the field of program administration identify themselves as teachers, scholars, and administrators. These documents, which include curriculum vitae, teaching philosophies, administrative vision statements, and research statements, are frequently requested when applying for jobs and are used to create a job applicant's dossier. In other words, more work should be done to answer this question: "How do professionals advocate for their stakeholders (i.e. students, colleagues, community members) from within their own positionalities in terms of academic job status (i.e. tenured or non-tenured) and (un)marked identities (i.e. race, ethnicity sexuality, gender status)? I argue that one way to fill this gap is by studying professional documents like diversity statements. The purpose of this study is to provide insight into writing studies professionals' experiences encountering job market diversity statements. This was a necessary measure if I wanted to assemble best practices on this specific writing task once the data collection and analysis was completed. On a broader scale, I hope to expand the current knowledge of how the field of writing studies—as a scholarly and praxis-driven discipline— conceptualizes commitments to diversity, equity, and inclusion across various job types. These include teaching, but also administration, scholarship, and service to the profession. As such, my research questions aim at identifying the ways my interview and survey participants (writers and readers of diversity statements): a)define each of the following terms: diversity, equity, and inclusion; b) articulate their understanding of a diversity statement's task and purpose; c) identify and reflect on the choices writers and readers make, including what writers include in their statements and the rationales they provide for these choices. To answer these questions, I employed thematic analysis to identify commonalities and differences between my participants' varied interactions with diversity statements. From these methods, I was able to make several tentative findings and point towards implications and further areas of study. Drawing from this data, this study assembles participants' recommended best practices for writing and reviewing diversity statements. It offers two contributions to the discipline. First, it provides a current portrait of what kinds of theories, actions, and values get highlighted in diversity statements. Second, I invite conversations about how employees throughout varied scholarly disciplines and job titles in higher education should use the diversity statement to take action against power structures that cause injustice to our students, colleagues, and communities.
